To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

We are to have a Christmas tree for the school children before the present term closes. I did not receive the quarterly allowance for prizes in October—may I purchase prizes for the children to the amount of five dollars?

I trust the Department will favorably consider a request for at least four slides for the children. They, especially the girls have no means of amusement during winter season and I do think the slides would be a source of encouragement for them to attend regularly.

I am doing my very best to make the school and school work attractive as possible.

The slides can be purchased here for fifty cents a piece. Mrs. Shaw makes them.

Trusting the Department will add this one more favor to many others.

I am,

West Bay Indian School,
Nov. 23, 1916.

Respectfully Yours,
Mary E. Burke.
Sir,

I enclose herewith letter from Miss Mary Burke, teacher West Bay School, which explains itself.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 1, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo enclosing a communication from Miss Mary Burke, teacher of the West Bay school, in which she asks to be allowed to purchase prizes for the children to the amount of $5.00 and also four sleds for them at fifty cents each.

In reply I beg to say that you may expend the sum of $7.00 in the purchase of prizes and sleds for the children attending this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. Russell McGregor, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.

I feel confident that if your department will make further inquiries if you deem such necessary after this letter you will pay the account and I would be pleased if you would send me or Mr. George cheque for same if you deem these statements sufficient.

Gore Bay, Ont., June 26th 1917

J. B. McLean Esq.
Secretary Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:— Mr. F. E. George of Gore Bay has handed me copy of your letter to Mr. J. Russell McGregor, acting Indian Agent, with respect to Mr. George's account for lumber dated 30th December last.

I feel sure that inquiry by your department will show that the account is just and true and that your department will not refuse to pay it.

I may say the lumber was regularly ordered by Mr. F. E. Baxter, your agent here under authority. It was duly manufactured under instructions of Mr. Baxter. It was piled at the most convenient place for loading within a short time after the order was given. It was to be removed by Mr. Baxter as soon as possible, but he did not get it away from there where piled it was burned.

For some reason known only to your Mr. Baxter it was left there for several months. Mr. George several times spoke to Mr. Baxter to permit Mr. George to sell it but your agent would not permit this as he figured on getting it away as he informed Mr. George.

The lumber was piled on the side of the road where directed. Under ordinary circumstances this lumber kept in stock by Mr. George was always kept in his buildings and never piled outside.
Ottawa, 5th February, 1917.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo with reference to the claim of Mr. R.E. George against the Department for lumber ordered by the late Agent Mr. Baxter, and note your observations with respect to this matter.

In reply I beg to say that the representations made in your letter with respect to the ordering and disposal of this lumber were set forth in a letter from Mr. George on the 4th August last and were considered before writing Mr. George on the 20th December last. It appears that Mr. Baxter ordered this siding but had not taken it away when the fire occurred so that he did not get the siding that he ordered. While Mr. George, as alleged, asked Mr. Baxter if he might dispose of the siding that was available for Mr. Baxter and supply other siding in its place. There does not appear to be anything to show that Mr. George had not a perfect right to do this without any reference to Mr. Baxter. The reason apparently for this reference was that Mr. George wanted to be sure of having the siding for Mr. Baxter when he called. With this view of the matter it does not appear that the Department could be properly called upon to pay this claim.

Your obedient servant,

John H. Craig, Esq.,
Solicitor, etc.,
Gore Bay, Ont.,
Asst. Deputy and Secret.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of 14th March I beg to report that hardwood floor and platform which should be larger than one new there would cost about $100. The flooring will have to be brought in from Collingwood or Owen Sound as since our factory was burned there is no dry kiln here and their flooring would not be satisfactory, the present floor while not good and hard to keep clean might do for another year but would be the better of a new one.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ottawa, June 15, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant stating that a new hardwood floor and platform for the West Bay school would cost about $100.00 and that the present floor, while not good and hard to keep clean, might do for another year.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to go to the expense of putting a new floor in this school at the present time, as you state the old one might do for another year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to reply to your letter of May 19th re repairs to West Bay School as follows:

I have been unable to get a price from local painters as they are very busy and have some schools to paint during the holidays; at the time this should be done, but it might be done by local men, but they would hardly be able to mix the paint and mixed might not be satisfactory for outside work, and it would have to be done by day work as none would take a contract.

As regards the floor it is all alike and the only thing that would improve it would be a new floor, the present one being pine and cracks allow the dirt to lodge and teacher complains that it is hard to sweep and is dusty when being done. I made request at one time for floor base or some preparation to use to keep the dust down when floor was being swept and request not granted. A new floor if put down should be hardwood and none satisfactory could be procured on the Island, and the cost for a No.1 or XXX maple would be about $185. to $175. and if done I would suggest that teachers platform would be deeper.

I find that the supports of bell are useless and require new frame, it has been braced as some time but now requires all new, and would probably cost $10. or $15.00.

June 9th, 1921.

MEMORANDUM

MR. SCOTT,

The Agent, Separate School Inspector and Teacher have drawn attention from time to time to the condition of the school building at West Bay. They state that the school building requires painting both inside and out, and the plaster needs repairing; the floor is in very poor condition and the building needs to be re-floored. The supports of the bell are useless, and when the bell is rung the whole building shakes. A new frame and a strong brace for its support are required.

The Agent was requested to forward an estimate of the cost of having the above work done, and the building put in a good state of repair. With reference to the painting, he states that he has been unable to secure a price from any of the local painters, but suggests that the work be done by day labour; the paint required to be purchased and supplied properly mixed. The material would cost approximately $100.00 and the labour about $100.00.

Regarding the flooring; the Agent suggests that it should be of hardwood, and as the flooring required could not be obtained on the Island (Manitoulin) it would cost about $175.00 delivered at the school. The labour and finishing (ciling) would cost approximately $80.00.

It would require an expenditure of about $15.00 to provide supports and braces for the bell tower.

The total expenditure required to put the building in a good state of repair would be approximately $300.00.

The West Bay Band, Account #251, have not sufficient funds to their credit in interest account, but have to their credit in capital account $105,326.60, and as these repairs would represent a capital expenditure, I would suggest that the funds be taken from the capital at the credit of the Band, and that an Order-In-Council be obtained approving of this being done.

If you consider that these repairs should be undertaken this summer, I would request that the necessary instructions be given to have the Order-In-Council prepared, and afterwards to authorize the Agent to have the work done.

Sir,

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Minister of Indian Affairs, reporting that the Indian Day School on the West Bay Indian Reserve, on Manitoulin Island in the Province of Ontario is in need of repair, it being pointed out by the Indian Agent, the Separate School Inspector and the teacher of the school, that the building requires painting inside and out, that it needs to be re-floored and that new supports should be supplied for the bell; that the cost of the necessary repairs are estimated by the Department of Indian Affairs as follows:— painting $250.00, re-flooring $255.00, and new supports for bell $15.00; $520.00 in all.

The Superintendent General therefore recommends that under the provisions of Section 89 of the Indian Act, authority be given for the above mentioned expenditure of $520.00 being made from the capital at the credit of the West Bay band, which amounts to $105,326.60.

The Board concur in the above recommendation and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

OTTAWA, August 3rd, 1921.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of June 4th, last, regarding the repairs required to the West Bay School building, I beg to say that authority for the expenditure required has been approved from the capital at the credit of the West Bay Band. I have, therefore, to request that you will take immediate steps to have the building painted, both inside and outside, the plaster repaired, where required, new floor laid and supports to the bell strengthened and put in good condition.

Regarding the painting, it is noted that you were unable to obtain prices from local painters and you recommend that this work be done by day labour. It will be necessary for you to purchase the paint and oils required, which should be of a good grade of material, and before making the purchase of the quantity required, you should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers and purchase from the one quoting you the lowest price. You should see that the paint is properly mixed. The amount authorized for this work is $150 for the material and $100 for the labour, and this should not be exceeded.

Regarding the flooring required, you should also arrange for the purchase of the quantity required, which should be of a good grade of hard wood flooring. It will also be necessary to obtain competitive prices before making the purchase, and the purchase made from the firm quoting you the lowest price. The expenditure for the cost of the material and labour, and oiling the floor after it is laid, should not exceed $75.

The expenditure in providing supports and braces for the bell, and the labour, should not exceed $15.00.

The Department will expect you to see that the above work is carried out in a satisfactory manner, and, if possible, completed before the end of the present month in order that the school building will be ready to reopen after the holidays. You should give the work your frequent oversight, and see that it is being done satisfactorily.

When the work has been completed, you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred to which should be attached a memorandum showing the names of the firms quoted by you to quote prices and the prices quoted by them in each case for the paint and hard wood flooring.

Dear Sir,

Two days ago I wrote to Mr. Draper, Indian Agent, begging him to obtain for Seal Bay Day School a cistern. As I feared that I had not sufficiently explained to him I thought best to write to you.

There is no well near Seal Bay School. We have to get our water from a spring which is at the foot of a steep hill. Though steps have been made it is very hard to carry all the water necessary.

For some reason the stone troughs which should have been used in the school were not finished and the work was left for this spring. If the Department would provide a cement tank to hold the water coming from the spring trough we could consider it a great favor.

A tank a cistern holding 10 or 12 ft. should I think be large enough to hold the water to be used for washing, etc., etc.
It possible this action could be placed just below the boiler which would secure surely prevent freezing or in case it could not be placed under the building at the place where the same trouble of the two sides can occur.

I would be most grateful if the Department would see fit to make this recommendation to the Street Board.

Thanking you in advance,

Most respectfully yours,
Elizabeth Lenehan.

Referring to your letter of May 27th last, I beg to advise that cistern at West Bay is really needed as all water has to be carried up a steep hill at rear of school, and if put in it would have to be outside of building, and should be about 15 barrels capacity, and be covered with double cover of cedar with air space and no danger from frost and labor should be got on the reserve and I could supervise the cement work by being there one day.

OTTAWA, June 9th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th inst., furnishing an estimate of the cost of installing a cistern at the West Bay Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that as the Department is anxious to provide an adequate water supply for this school, and to overcome the difficulty at present existing whereby all water required has to be carried up a steep hill, authority is granted you to have a cistern installed of the capacity mentioned by you. It is noted that the labour required in the cement work can be obtained on the Reserve, so that you will supervise the work. The cistern should be installed in a manner to prevent freezing. A pump, sink and drain should also be installed, and the pump connected with the cistern. The entire cost of the cistern and pump, including the material and labour, should not exceed approximately $100, and a less amount, if possible.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands, and will expect that a satisfactory job is carried out, so that when the cistern is completed it will be frost proof, and will be adequate to serve the purpose for which it is required. It should be so arranged that the water from the eaves-troughs can be collected and run into the cistern.

When the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred for both the material and the labour required.

In the purchase of any material required, competitive prices should, if possible, be obtained, and the purchase made from the firm quoting the lowest price.

You should give this matter your early attention and, if possible, have the work completed during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

Here's what I've done:

I've written to the local council to express my concern about the lack of proper waste management facilities in our community. I've also attended several town hall meetings to voice my concerns.

I'm not sure what else I can do, but I believe it's important to take action now before it's too late.
I have been here for some time now, and I am very glad to be able to see you again after such a long absence. It seems like only yesterday when we last met, and yet it feels like years ago. I miss you so much, and I hope you are well.

I have been working hard to earn a living, and I am grateful for any opportunity that comes my way. I am trying to save money so that I can provide for myself and my family. It is not easy, but I am determined to succeed.

I am looking forward to seeing you soon, and I hope we can catch up on everything that has happened since we last spoke. I miss you so much, and I am grateful for your friendship.

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the West Bay Indian Day School, states that some of the desks are broken; that the stove is set on bricks and that a new stove should be supplied. He also states that the blackboards should be refinished, and that a supply of drinking cups and window shades should be furnished.

Please also furnish a report regarding the condition of the blackboards and state what is required to have them placed in a good state of repair.

You may arrange for the purchase and installation of 7 new window shades of the size required. The teacher will be able to give you the dimensions.

You may also purchase a small number of granite ware drinking cups, and you should forward recently certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the blinds and drinking cups.

The Inspector has drawn attention to the accommodation provided in the present classroom, which he states is far too small to accommodate the number of pupils who could attend. He states the seating capacity is for 35 pupils only; that the room is crowded and that the enrollment is only a little more than half the number that should attend. The present classroom is 30' x 20' x 48', which only gives 129 cubic feet of air space per child. Ordinary health requirements demand that 250 cubic feet of air space per child be provided. He recommends that an addition be built to the present classroom by an extension to the building of at least 15 feet or more, if required. More cloak room space is also required.

I have to request that you will make full enquiry regarding the accommodation, and furnish a report regarding the size of the addition required to the present building to provide ample accommodation for all the Indian children who would attend.

Ottawa, May 25th, 1927.

Sir,

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the West Bay Indian Day School, recommends that the following equipment be supplied for the use of the school and teacher's residence:

- 3 kitchen chairs
- 1 broom
- 3 sheets
- 2 pillow cases

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of these supplies. While serviceable articles should be obtained, they should be purchased as cheaply as possible.

The Inspector further states that a lock is required for the dining-room door. You may purchase same and arrange to have it installed.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred for the above authorized purchases.

The Inspector has drawn attention of the condition of the toilets. He states that they are in a terrible condition and should be replaced. He also recommends that the interior of the teacher's residence be painted. I have to request that you will forward a report regarding the toilets and painting. You should state whether it is necessary that new toilets be erected and, if so, you should give an approximate cost of having the work done. Please report, also, regarding the painting mentioned and give an estimate of the cost of having same done, stating whether or not you would recommend that this work be carried out. Your early attention to the above will oblige.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Replying to yours of the 26th, re. Sperate School Inspector's report on West Bay Indian School I have to report that it is quite necessary to have new toilets erected, and I have made enquiries as to the probable cost and find that it will be approximately $40.00 for each toilet.

Regarding the painting the interior of the teacher's residence, this was given one coat at the time it was built and Miss Lavalle wished it to be left until Spring; it was never completed, and I would recommend that same be done during the summer vacation. The paint and varnish figuring will cost in the neighborhood of $20.00, and getting it put on $28.00, and I possibly will have to buy some brushes, possibly $1.75.

Your Obedient Servant

Wm. Jackson
Acting Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 2nd, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, regarding the erection of two new toilets in connection with the West Bay Indian Day School and stating the approximate cost of same; also regarding the painting of the interior of the teacher's residence.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange during the present summer to have two separate toilets erected, and the work should be carried out as inexpensively as possible. You should purchase the material and arrange for the labour. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that a satisfactory job is completed. Padlocks should be installed on the door of each closet and the keys kept in the possession of the teacher.

Relative to the painting of the interior of the teacher's residence, you may arrange during the summer holidays to have this painting performed. You should purchase the paint, varnish, brushes, etc., and arrange for the labour. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained in the purchase of the paint required and for the lumber, etc., for the toilets.

You should see that all work is finished to your satisfaction, and, when completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the material and also for the labour.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the West Bay Indian Day School, states that the school building is badly in need of painting, also that steps should be taken to provide a water supply for the use of the school. Please state whether you would advise that this school building be painted this summer or not, and, if so, you should give full particulars as to the amount of painting required and the approximate cost of same and how you would recommend that the work be carried out. I may say that our funds are very limited and, unless this painting is urgent, we would not be prepared to authorize having it done this summer. The Department will, however, await your report as to the amount of painting required, cost, etc.

Please also furnish your views relative to the providing of a well at this school, or what other means you would recommend in furnishing a supply of water. You should give an estimate of the cost of any work which you would recommend be carried out for the purpose.

Sir,

With reference to official letter file No 12-4-5 July 8th 1930 I beg to advise that the school at West Bay would be the better for painting but it is not absolutely necessary and would not hurt to have it left till next year. The cost of painting the school and residence attached with a good grade of paint and the work done by an experienced man would be around $250.00.

The water for the school has always been obtained from a spring creek at the back of the school and water from this creek is also used by a good many residents in the village as well. Digging and drilling in the vicinity has always proven a failure in your official letter file No 12-4-5 Nov. 26th 1928 permission was given for me to have a new set of steps built down to the creek but as winter set in so early I could not get the work done but explained to Mr McGookin on his visit to the school what was intended and he thought same would be satisfactory and I am therefore having the steps put in now before school resumes.

I would recommend leaving the painting of the school until next summer.

Sir:

Miss Wrinn, teacher of the West Bay Indian Day School, visited the Department on the 23rd instant and stated that the Ontario Hydro Power lines now pass close to the school. She requested that the school and residence be wired for lighting purposes and connected up with the power line.

I would request that, at your early convenience, you furnish an estimate of the cost of the wiring and fixtures required to satisfactorily light the residence and classroom and also the cost of extending the wire from the power line to the school. You should state, also, the rates that would be charged for supplying the current for lighting purposes. I may add, that it is doubtful if the Department can provide the funds for this purpose, but it is desired to have this information.

The teacher requested, further, that the entire plot of ground in connection with the school be fenced next spring; or, if not possible to fence the entire plot, that sufficient ground be fenced for garden purposes. She stated that, if a garden was conducted and properly fenced, she would teach the children gardening and also that she would be prepared to attend a summer course in Agriculture at Guelph next summer.

I would request that you give an estimate of the cost of the materials required and the labour for the purpose of erecting a fence around the entire school grounds. Further, please submit a separate report regarding the cost of material and labour for fencing a sufficient quantity of ground for garden purposes only. The above information should be supplied at your early convenience, in order that consideration can be given to the question of providing lighting facilities and also the fencing.

Sir;

Sir:

With reference to the drinking water used at West Bay School, I have to advise that this water is obtained from a creek that runs just outside the school yard and has its source about three miles from the school where it comes out of a side of a hill but it flows through the reserve and in some cases right through the barn yards and close to stables etc.

Last spring there was quite a outbreak of intestinal troubles in and around the village at West Bay where a lot of people got their drinking water from this creek. Miss Wright, head girl forwarded two samples of water to Toronto for analysis, No 1 was taken from the creek and No 2 was taken from the cistern. I have enclosed the report with regard to this water.

I am informed by the Indians that a few years ago a well was drilled on the school grounds and water was obtained at 40 ft but this did not satisfy the drillers and they went deeper and came up with the result that no water was obtained at all, therefore it is considered by the Indians that if another well is drilled at the 40 ft level it will be successful. However, there are dug wells near by which are not over 20 ft deep.

There is a hill rising out of the school grounds about eight miles from here and I would like to make an inquiry for drilling at a point that is about 1,700 feet above sea level.

May your expedition be successful and satisfactory.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the drilling of a well at the West Bay Indian Day School. In this connection it is noted you consider that there is every likelihood of obtaining water if the well was drilled to a depth of 40 ft., requiring an expenditure of approximately $100.

The Department will approve of you arranging to have this well drilled, to a depth not exceeding 40 ft. It is hoped that a supply of water can be obtained at less depth, but, in the event that water is not obtained at a depth of 40 ft., you should communicate with the Department before proceeding to drill deeper. At the same time, you should submit a further report as to the prospect of obtaining water and the additional depth you consider it would be necessary to drill.

Our funds are extremely limited, and it is hoped that a good supply of water can be obtained without the necessity of going beyond a depth of 40 ft. Sir,

With reference to official letter 1-4-5 Oct. 23rd last re drilling of well at West Bay school, I beg to advise that I engaged Mr. Harrison Neville of Mindemoya to manage drill this well at $3 per foot and he to furnish the casing.

Mr. Neville called me yesterday to go down to West Bay and I have to report that after going 30 feet down he has struck quick sand and although there is water there he has to go below the quick sand as it only fills up the casing, as a matter of fact it was four feet up in the casing yesterday.

I instructed Mr. Neville to go down another ten or fifteen feet to see if he could get out of the quick sand and strike water that would be suitable.

Mr. Neville is convinced that he can get water even if he has to go beyond the 40 or 45 feet depth but I advised him that without instructions from The Department I could not allow him to go more than another 10 or 15 feet.

Mr. Neville has drilled five wells previous to this one this summer and has never failed to get water, he states that the lowest he has had to go any place was 65 feet.

This well at the school is badly needed as the creek water is not fit to drink and although they have used it in the past there has been epidemics of stomach sickness on different occasions.

Since Mr. Neville feels so confident of getting water I would like to be able to advise him to continue drilling operations until he does get water.

Your obedient servant

Memorandum:

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memoranda of June 23 and June 25 in connection with representations made in a letter from Mr. Thos. Farquhar, M. P., regarding the West Bay Indian Day School.

A new well was drilled at this school in June, 1936, and I have been unable to locate on our file any report showing that the water was injurious to the health of the children. I might add that it is not our usual practice to install electrically operated pumps in Indian Day Schools, not only on account of the primary cost but also the maintenance of such installation is a constant cause for expenditure. I note that you have been informed that it would require approximately $300.00 for the installation mentioned in your correspondent's letter. No funds for this purpose have been provided in our current year's appropriation.

However, as requested by Mr. Pratt the Indian Agent is being written and requested to report immediately. As soon as his reply is received the matter will have further consideration and another memorandum will be submitted to you.

Director.
Ottawa,
June 28, 1938.

Dear Sir:

It has been reported to the Department that the West Bay Indian Day School requires some alterations and repairs. It has also been urged that water be brought into the building and in this regard our correspondent writes as follows:

"That the only source of water supply is a nearby creek of which the water is highly polluted with typhoid germs; that two wells have been drilled but both were failures.

"That not far from the School, say around 600 ft., there is good spring water which comes out of the ground; that this spring is on the other side of the creek, thus making it difficult to reach.

"It is suggested that the water from this spring could be brought into the school without much difficulty if an electric pump were installed; that the electricity with which to run the pump could easily be procured as the Hydro runs through there, and that there is a transformer at the school gate.

"It is stated that every Fall there is an outbreak of Dysentery among the children and the Doctors maintain it is caused by the impure water from this creek; that Dr. Davis condemned this creek years ago.

"That the estimated cost of having this work done would be in the neighbourhood of $300.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitoulin, Ont.
"It is represented that the health of the children being so essential, the need is very urgent."

Please visit this school immediately and let me have a complete report as soon as possible regarding the West Bay School. You should report fully on any repairs or alterations necessary, giving an estimate of their cost. You should also comment on the representations made to us regarding the proposed installation of a new water system.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have the honour to report that I visited this school recently and made an investigation of the water supply. The two wells which have been drilled are both total failures. The supply intended for use at the school has been carried from a spring creek near the school, and from this creek a large number of the Indian families get their supply of water. There is another shallow spring, which your correspondent refers to, but this spring contains the water in its mouth, and no doubt there are found in the spring, or within a short distance of it, plenty of water, besides it would be costly to force the water from the spring by means of a electric pump as I have seen in other cases. It might be well to lay a short pipe across the creek near the school and this would enable water to be carried from the spring for drinking purpose. A suitable bridge should not cost over $100.00, or it might be advisable to have the supply of drinking water required delivered by the Bay which is only a short distance from the school.

There is another shallow spring, which your correspondent refers to, but during the spring months the water in this spring would not be any more pure than in the spring creek where at present they get their supply of water, besides it would be costly to force the water from the spring to the school by an electric pump as it is over 1,000 feet away from the school building. Sir:

With further reference to Departmental Letter No. 12-4-5 of January 28th last, in regard to a water supply for the West Bay Indian Day School, I have to report that during the winter months the water from the spring creek that runs through the corner of the school lot is fit for use, but when the spring opens it seems to be impure. Water cannot be obtained by digging in the school yard as several wells have been put down in the vicinity of the school and all have been a failure. The only means to try and solve the water problem at this school would be to have a well put down on the bank of the creek a short distance from the school. It would be necessary to dig down to several feet below the level of the creek, put a galvanized steel crib of 23" diameter, and have a ditch of about two feet wide to the bottom of the creek and fill with good gravel to the bottom of the well so all water entering would be filtered, and as the creek never has gone dry it would mean a lasting supply of good water, which they have never had yet.

I have had Mr. Oliver Bond a contractor of Mindemoya make an estimate on the cost of this work and he is willing to dig the well, supply the galvanized steel crib, put a good lumber top on crib covering it with galvanized iron so that no dirt can get in, and would repair the present pump in the old well to first class repair and install it in new well leaving everything in fair-perfect-working order for the sum of $110.00.

This would appear to me to be the cheapest and most satisfactory means to get a supply of water to the school and teacher's residence. The work should be carried out before the middle of March in order to miss the flood water, as the well would have to be an approx. depth of 22 feet.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Ferguson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 14, in which you ask that the lighting facilities at the East Bay Indian Day School, in your constituency, be investigated by the Department.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that the Branch has not at any time installed electric lighting facilities at Indian day schools, although the matter has been investigated on a number of occasions. Correspondence on file indicates that the Hydro Electric Power Commission of Ontario are not prepared to supply electrical energy to Indian day schools unless this Department, as owner of the premises, signs a contract guaranteeing the payment of all charges incurred in connection with the electrical service. In view of this and a number of other conditions, it has never been considered advisable to proceed with the installation of electric lighting at our schools.

On dull days a number of teachers take up vocational instruction, such as knitting, crochet work for girls and carpentry and wood carving for boys. It is just possible that the teacher of the East Bay School might be encouraged to follow this practice.

The Indian agent will be asked to visit this school and to make an investigation of the existing lighting facilities with the object of having them improved, if improvement is at all possible.

Sir:

In reply to your letter No.12-45 dated April 21, 1939 in regards to the lighting facilities at the West Bay School, I beg to say, I measured the windows while in west Bay on Saturday paying Robinson Treaty Annuity; and, I find the school is well provided with windows with windows of large size but are all on the north side of building which cannot be avoided, because the residence is situated on the south side.

There are 5 windows which take up the full size of the north wall, there being eighteen lights 12 X 14 inches in each window, so there does not seem to be much that can be done in the way of altering the windows in the class room; but it does seem that we should have electric energy in the residence at least when the power line passes so near the building. Should the supplying of electric energy for the residence be considered, I am sure the extra cost of lighting the class room would be negligible as one contract should cover both residence and class room when the buildings are combined. A five year contract is all you are asked for now whereas formerly it was necessary to sign a twenty year contract.

Under present circumstances, I would strongly recommend the advisability of reconsidering the claim of this school for electric lighting.

Yours very truly,

The Department is in receipt of your voucher No. 40-92 covering the cost of removing storm windows and cleaning the toilets at the West Bay School.

Sir:

I have for acknowledgement your letter No.12-4-5 dated May 17, 1940, in regard to duties of caretaker.

It is impossible to get this adjusted immediately, as apparently the present caretakers were engaged by the former agent with the understanding that such jobs as cutting grass and weeds, removing storm windows, screens etc. were not included in the caretakers duties.

I would suggest that we get this straightened out at the beginning of the next school term, and have it distinctly understood what their duties are.

In regard to splitting wood, with the exception of two or three schools, the kitchen wood was purchased split ready for use, and was paid for accordingly, and I will endeavour next year to have it all supplied in this way.

In most cases the salary paid as caretaker does not cover what she pays out to Indians for sweeping, scrubbing etc.; as most of them hire the work done, partly to help the Indians out, but where the teacher resides at the school, it is better to appoint her as caretaker, so she can oversee the work anyway.

Sir:-

The drainage system from the kitchen sink at West Bay School went out of commission early last winter and has been cause for considerable annoyance and inconvenience to Mr. and Mrs. Joyce ever since.

I prevailed with them to put up with it until the frost went out in the spring, as it would be difficult and expensive to get a good job in the winter time.

The old arrangement was a timber cess pool outside the building with a part board drain and has always given considerable trouble in the winter time. The old trap is all worn out, and as there is no basement in the building, we think much better service would be received with having a cess pool built up with rock directly beneath the sink underneath the building, eliminating the difficulty from frost, the estimated cost of which is $23.25.

Mr. Oliver Bond has given me a quotation on a complete new system, which I think is very reasonable, and I would recommend that I be authorized to make the alterations without delay. Mr. Bond's estimate is enclosed herewith.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

This expense was an emergency case and could not be avoided. The casing got broken, short tire peg, and the teacher, Mr. Joyce took the part off and set it aside at his own expense. Another small casing which is attached to the broken part, was screwed back on the sucker rod while the part was sent away for welding, and while Mr. Joyce was away over a weekend, some mischievous person, probably children, took the threaded casing off, put a lot of gravel stones down the pipe and also put a lot of refuse, tin cans etc., in the well, which necessitated pulling the job out, taking the cylinder apart to remove the gravel stones and thoroughly clean the well.

The top has now been made secure so that it cannot be lifted without some tools.

January 5, 1943

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to report a fire has occurred at the Fox School as a result of a defective chimney.

The three walls of chimney which are exposed appear to be in perfect condition, but the fire started between the chimney and outside wall, and when exposed to view the outside wall of chimney proved to have a few small vents where there was no mortar between the bricks.

The insurance adjuster has assessed the damage, which is the amount for which Mr. L. A. Buck of Little Current has agreed to repair the damage.

It will not be possible to complete the repairs immediately as some of the material is not available, but Mr. Buck assured me he would repair it now sufficient to carry on with school work, and will complete the work as soon as the material is available.

I would advise having the chimney rebuilt next summer as at the present time, it is not possible to do more than repair the defective part of chimney where the fire originated.

C. R. Johnston, Esq., Indian Agent, Manitouining, Ontario,

I wish to refer to your voucher No. 43-223 dated July 28, 1943, in favour of L. A. Buck, Little Current, Ontario, in the amount of $50.00, for balance of contract on repairs to West Bay School, as a result of fire which occurred on December 26, 1942.

It is noted you are far from satisfied with the repairs as effected by Mr. Buck. It is requested that you insist on the job being done to your satisfaction so that you can conscientiously sign a voucher for the balance due. It may be that the contract was not definite enough in its terms to enable you to pin Mr. Buck to a certain standard of efficiency in completing the job. However, it is noted that you consider the chimney is still unsafe. It is considered that to make the chimney safe was the essence of the contract and therefore, you should be able to safely insist on this being done.

Your voucher No. 43-223 is returned herewith and when the work is properly completed will you please let us have an amended voucher covering the expenditure.

You will find enclosed requisition for supplies for use at West Bay Indian Day School during the coming academic year.

The needs of this school have been carefully estimated, and the supplies listed are quite urgently needed. As there are some additional items which will be attended to in school, the order will not be required for a few weeks. The prices quoted on the list were from Christie's Limited, and I would refer to have you purchase the supplies to West Bay School, Tweedsmuir, Ontario, via Toronto, to little current, Ontario. The stove at this school is altogether beyond repair and in need of an immediate replacement. I can secure a fine new one with reasonable cost from C. W. Wilson, Whitewater, Ontario.

I would request that you give this matter your earliest attention.

September 11, 1944

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

In a recent hail storm which swept through part of the Island, twenty six panes of glass were broken in West Bay School, and should be replaced at once.

There are a number of other window panes which should have new putty, also some floors to paint and varnish; and a new ladder constructed for use at the school to reach the top windows, and eaves of the roof. The well requires cleaning out, and a lot of undergrowth in the school grounds should be cleaned out. The platform and steps at class room entrance, and the school bell need repairing; and I enclose herewith a requisition for the necessary material.

I would estimate the cost of labour at $50.00, which will be done mostly by Indians, and would be pleased to receive an advance cheque for this amount to pay wages.

C. H. Johnston,
Indian Agent
Ottawa, September 15, 1944.

Manitowaning, Ontario.

November 29, 1946

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for the Village School at West Bay Reserve.

Miss Des Coteaux informs me that the school is very poorly furnished and short of supplies. She particularly complained that the bed was not fit to sleep on, and has also requested to have a partition made in the kitchen which is 12' X 22' so that she can have a bedroom downstairs, as it is very cold upstairs. Some of the walls and ceilings are done with murocco, which are scaly and shabby and requests to have these painted.

Some of the doors fit poorly etc., and altogether I would estimate $100.00 will be required for labour.

The quotations were secured from C.W. Hinds and S.W. McPhee & Co. of Manitowaning, and T. Eaton's Catalogue.

Miss DesCoteaux brought a gas stove with her, and has requested to be supplied with gasoline for this as well as coal oil for lighting. I presume the gas stove would conserve other fuel, particularly during Spring and Fall, and would recommend this be supplied. Apparently Miss DesCoteaux had coal oil supplied where she taught in other agencies, while in this agency, Shehegwaning is the only instance where coal oil for light has been supplied.

I cannot offer any explanation for this, and I would suggest there should be uniformity. I would estimate from 15 to 20 gallons per year for each school would be sufficient.

I would recommend local purchase of these supplies as per quotations at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

O.R. Johnston,
Indian Agent
Ottawa, 3 December 1946.

MANITOWANING, Ontario.

Bernard J. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for West Bay Village School, most of which are made necessary by the addition of a second class-room.

The quotations are from C.W. Hinds, S.W. McPhee & Co. of Manitowaning, A.J. Wagg of Mindemoya and a few articles from Eaton's catalogue.

The teacher, Mrs. Rita Corbiere, has already purchased the knives, forks, spoons and soft balls. There was not sufficient cutlery in the school to carry on with and these had to be purchased immediately.

I have informed Mrs. Corbiere she should not have purchased the soft balls as these are usually supplied by the Department, however, they were already in use and I could not return them.

There are still a few old double seats and desks in use in this school and by supplying thirty new single desks, it is considered the old ones can be discarded. Please have these supplied by the Purchasing Agent.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent.

We have been advised that our estimates have been tabled in the House and that therefore we can anticipate funds being available for the construction of two schools in your agency. I enclose herewith a resolution passed in Council by Manitoulin Island Unceded Band requesting Day Schools be erected on the reserve, one at the Matangowi Settlement, and one at South Bay.

This matter has been previously considered and it was proposed at one time last year to rent a house at the Matangowi Settlement to open a school. Taking into consideration the pupils that are in Spanish Residential School from this district there would be approximately thirty pupils attend this school, a great many of whom are too far from Wikwemikong, the nearest school. As previously stated, I consider the settlers are too scattered at South Bay to warrant the building of a school there at present.

Although a school is needed at the Matangowi Settlement, I wish to point out again that West Bay Reserve should have the first consideration. We have a farm house rented there now for three terms and which is altogether unsatisfactory. There are thirty-six pupils on the roll with adequate space for about half that number. The owner of the house is living in cramped quarters to make his house available for a school and has positively refused to rent the house another winter. When I first made the arrangement to rent the farm house, I advised the owner it was expected it would be only for one term and had great difficulty in getting his consent for last term and then only by raising the rental by $10.00 per month.

I would suggest by all means a new school should be erected here this summer and if it is possible to erect two schools in the Agency, the Matangowi settlement should have second consideration.

Inspection of West Bay Indian Day School.

This school is now operating as a three-room school with two separate units. At the one school, we have an old building which was added to approximately fifteen years ago. There are two classrooms which are fairly satisfactory. At this school there are two teachers:

(1) Miss Virginia Trudeau - She is an Indian girl aged nineteen who after spending two years at St. Joseph's College in North Bay was living at Wikwemikong. We hired her to complete the rest of the school year. She is teaching the Senior room which is a fairly good classroom. There are six windows providing light from the proper side. These children tested well and it is obvious that with a qualified teacher good work could be done with them. Miss Trudeau will only be continuing in this school until the end of June.

(2) Miss B. Bruyere - This teacher has no qualifications but had five years in our normal schools. She is a natural teacher and has the primary room doing very well in their work. Unfortunately, this room is a converted part of the house but it is adequate for the present time. It was formerly a classroom which was brought into use as a bedroom and is now back in use as a classroom.

The teacher's quarters are attached to the old part of the school and is definitely in need of insulation. My recommendations are as follows:
(1) That Mr. Doucet visit this school during the summer holidays when he is inspecting the new buildings at Lakewiew and Murray Hill.

(2) That arrangements be made to insulate the hall and the entire second floor with ten feet.

(3) A new door and storm door are required for the hall.

(4) The entrance hall should be provided for use by the children entering the classroom. At the present time, we are losing a great deal of heat from the school door.

(5) Mr. Doucet could approach the owner of the Manitowaning Lodge who is a former contractor who told me that he would tender on any repair work or new construction. He will not be available, of course, until October.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

September 11, 1948.

Mr. C.R. Johnston, Supt. of Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

From his recent visit to several schools in your Agency, Mr. Doucet reports the following:

1. Wikwemikong Indian Day School - The school plumbing is leaking between the two floors above the kitchen. The Agent has been authorized to have this checked immediately and the necessary repairs made. The school roof leaks at two places. The Agent has been authorized to have this thoroughly inspected and have the spots where the leakage occurs re-shingled. This may entail a few shingles or a couple of square feet, however, as it is ruining the ceilings and walls, it was necessary to have this done immediately. Ceilings at the spot of leakage will have to be re-plastered. It is not more than a few square feet at each spot.

There is plenty of water in the well but apparently the cylinder of the pump is leaking and would need new leathers. The Agent has been asked to have this done. It should entail very little expense.

The Department confirms the decisions made by Mr. Doucet and wish you to have the above done as soon as possible.

We have received your wire re the condenser and coil for the electrical plant. These articles have been ordered through Fairbanks-Morse and will be forwarded to you as soon as they arrive.

2. West Bay Indian Day School. - A great deal of the cold air enters the kitchen from the foundation. This should be thoroughly banked with the surrounding soil in the Fall and in the Spring cleared away to prevent the lumber from decaying. Prices should be obtained immediately from an insulation company on insulating the school and building.
A storm porch approximately 5' x 6' should be built at the entrance of the second classroom.

The Department desires you to obtain prices for this insulation at your earliest convenience and also the cost of building the above mentioned porch.

3. Lakeview and Murray Hill - You are authorized to use the rock siding insul brick instead of the red brick for the Lakeview School and if the Company supplying the asbestos shingles for the siding of the Murray Hill School is willing to substitute the rock insul brick, you are hereby authorized to make this substitution.

Obtain a contract for the forced air stoker fed heating plant for the Lakeview two-room school and the gravity system with the automatic draft controls for the Murray Hill one-room Day School. Have these contracts sent to this office at your earliest convenience so that the construction of these buildings may not be held up by the heating installation.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

During August, 1948, surveyors came and took two acres of my land — good farm land, cleared, fenced, and seeded. This site was chosen for the building of the new school erected here.

Our Indian Agent, Mr. Johnston, told me to bring the matter of the sale and price of this two acres, into our meeting. The Council decided that I should charge fifty dollars per acre, bringing the price to one hundred dollars for the two acres.

I have written to Mr. Johnston over this matter, but he has failed to reply. I am a hard working man, and I need this money.

When they took this land, and had started to drill the well, seventeen horses got into my grain, because the horses did not keep the gate open. These animals ruined about twenty dollars worth of grain. And the Indian Agent promised me that he would make supply me with the fence. As yet, I haven't heard anything about the payment for the land nor any...
anything about the fence.

Please advise me concerning this matter.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Joe P. DeBassige

Ottawa, August 11, 1924.

Report on Whitefish Bay Reserve.

The next and most vital question taken up from the Indians' viewpoint was the education of their children. They admitted that when they had a Day School on the reserve years ago it was closed owing to the difficulty of getting the children to attend. It was pointed out to them that under the treaty the Department was not obliged to open a Day School on every reserve, but only as may be advisable. They were told that the Department had provided two schools in the Lake of the Woods District, one at Shoal Lake, and the other at Shoal Lake. The Indians replied that they would send their children to either of these schools. They complained of bad feeding, overcrowding, and wrongful punishment at the Kenora School. The boys they said spent a great deal of their time in sawing wood and when their children returned home they could not talk English. Girls also had been tied up, etc. They also heard bad reports of the Cecelia Jeffrey School at Shoal Lake, of immorality amongst the pupils, etc.

There are about 20 children of school age at this reserve and they were all lined up before us at the meeting. Solemn promises were made that they would keep their children at home during the school term if the Department would provide the teacher and they promised to erect the school building, if the Department would furnish such material as Roofing, Flooring, Doors, Sash, Windows, and Hardware. They will get the logs at this coming winter and only need to be supplied with a small quantity of provisions while performing the work.

As the cost to the Department will not be great, I told them that I would recommend to the Department that their offer be accepted. As most of these Indians are Pagans the school could be non-denominational. Capt. Edwards, however, is of the opinion that the school will not be a
success, that the Indians will take their children away from the Reserve, on hunting trips when they should be at school. As the cost of the building, however, will not be large, I feel bound to recommend another trial and leave it with the Department to decide. A large enough building will be erected by the Indians to permit of partitioning off one end of it in order to provide living quarters for the teacher. If it is decided to go ahead a plan should be sent to me that will show what Indians will have the dimensions of the logs they should get out.

x x x

A. H. Pratt,
Accountant.
Ottawa, September 11, 1924.

Sir:

Mr. Paget, of this Department, reports that there are 20 children of school age on the Whitefish Bay Reserve. The Department has decided to try a day school at this point, provided that there will be no large capital expense. You're authorized to purchase the roofing, flooring, doors, sash, windows and hardware that are necessary for the school building, which can be used for both classroom and teacher's residence.

The Indians have promised to get out the logs and to erect a building, giving their labour gratis. You may purchase materials for those engaged on the building. No unnecessary expenses should be incurred, and competitive prices should be sought before making the purchases. If an expenditure of more than $300 is necessary for finishing materials, please make an interim report and estimate.

A requisition for school desks and other classroom equipment should be forwarded when the commencement of the school has been assured.

It might be well for you to secure a promise in writing from the Chief and parents of the Band to the effect that the children will attend regularly for the periods the school is in operation. As the majority of the Indians have no church affiliation, the school will be non-denominational, under your supervision. When it is timely, you may make a recommendation regarding the engagement of a teacher. It is doubtful if a properly qualified incumbent could be persuaded to accept this position because of the living conditions. You should make enquiries, however, and, if possible, secure applications. I am prepared to allow a salary of only $500 and bonus, as the activity is somewhat of an experiment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Ass't Deputy Secretary.

Frank Edwards, P.E.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Sir,

Re: Whitefish Bay School.

Replying to your letter File No 129-8-1 dated September 11th 1924, your instructions contained therein will be strictly carried out.

Very little can be accomplished this fall in the matter of building other than the Indians cutting and preparing the logs, and when they are all ready the school building will be erected next spring.

I think that an expenditure of $300 would not be sufficient for finishing material, but when the time comes an estimate will be made and a report rendered.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 2-1 of this date, including correspondence of Mr. James Koehler of Kenora, who has returned recently, re School Teacher at Whitefish Bay Day School.

The Department was against operating a Day School in this Agency, but after a visit of Mr. F. T. Page of Ottawa, Mr. Robinson, and myself to Whitefish, it was decided to try one on a pilot scale.

A teacher was purchased from Chief Charlie Lacourciere, and Mr. Robinson was appointed teacher. He resigned and the present teacher, Mr. Lacourciere, was appointed by the Department in the recommendation of the Catholic priests. In connection to the school starting, we sent instructions from Ottawa, but a reply was not received.

Lacourciere is a French Canadian from Montreal, and the teachers in all the Catholic Schools in the Agency are of French descent.

Lacourciere was located upon as a good teacher, but after consultation with Mr. Greening, Separate School Inspector, it was decided to keep him, owing to the difficulty of getting another.

In connection to the trust children to the school, there is no lack of funds, mostly of Indian descent, to pay teacher teachers in the future, and we understand does not teach properly.

Dear Sir,

In this connection, the Chief of Whitefish informs me that Frank Edwards - the Indian agent at Kenora - is the main reason I am here for the employment of the recent teacher at Whitefish.

I may say that it was through my agitation in 1923, on behalf of the Indian people at Whitefish, that the school there was secured. Frank Edwards violently opposed everything that I suggested on their behalf, but everything in his power to prevent any new reform that was proposed on their behalf.

Without positive knowledge - my surmise is that it was the man who suggested a Frenchman as a teacher - he does not make little of what was gained through the employment of a Teacher.

All the people in the vicinity are English in race, and it is the English language especially that the Indians need and require.

I had not been down to that vicinity since 1923 till a couple of weeks ago, and only then did I learn that the Teacher was Frenchman. Naturally, wish to speak the French language and teach the French language. That has been a permanent calamity to the school. Even now the change would be disastrous.

Frank Edwards ever since his appointment here, has been violently opposed to everything that would advance the interests of the Indians in this agency, and the reason - he knew that was the attitude of his Chief, the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir:

Now that the school year is over I wish to advise you that I am well satisfied with the results obtained; I have done the very best I could. I have taken a real liking to this place & intend to bring my "bride" here shortly after the 25th. But, I sincerely believe that my present salary of $70 a month is not quite sufficient.

Of course there's the P.O. revenue but, since the K.C. mail has been passing through Eagle River during the winter months my salary warrant has diminished a great deal.

You are well aware of the conditions here. We must send to town for everything we need, the charges are very high; $3 a lb. by plane... Trips to town are also very expensive. At the time being
I am pursuing a course of studies (M.A. in Lett.) which necessitates my presence in Pteg every 4 mo. This course is costing me on the average for registration fees, books (etc.) between $5 & $6 a month apart from the travelling expenses.

When I first came up here the place was in a rather bad shape. There was no fence, no garden, no cupboards in the residence, not even a bedroom. I built a fence myself; then came the garden (soft by 26), then the rest: cupboards, partitions ceiling in the school (etc.), I have whitewashed the walls, painted the roof etc etc.

Another thing. Not one cent was spent by the depart for the buying & splitting of the wood for the school; not one cent was spent for the care of the schoolroom, the sweeping, scrubbing etc. This the teacher had to do himself or pay someone else to have it done.

I am very glad to have been of some use & I am purely ready to do the same thing over again but, I sincerely believe that $6 a month is the least
a married woman should expect under these circumstances.

I think that if you were willing to put in a good word for me to that effect I would get this little raise.

As the depart. has refused to provide me with cooking utensils, I bought myself an 8¢ pg. I also bought all my furniture for, as you know there is nothing here along that line.

Hoping that you will oblige me as you have already done so often & so well, I remain

Your faithfully,

I have received a letter from the School Teacher at Whitefish Bay Indian Day School, informing me that he is writing for his M.A. Examinations at the University of Manitoba; the examinations will most likely be held on Friday, April 26th. He would like to have leave of absence for the 4th to 26th.

I would recommend that permission be given, I do not know if his wife will accompany him or not, but she was a school teacher and could, if not going away, take his place, in any case he has done splendid work at this school, according to the Inspector, and I would recommend permission for this leave of absence be given with pay if possible.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa,
June 18, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant enclosing letter received from Mr. Laflèche, teacher of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

The Department regrets that owing to conditions existing at present our appropriation has been reduced and as a consequence funds are only available for salaries for teachers of Indian day schools for a nine-month period during the academic year 1940-41. As the deduction in the appropriation affects the current year's vote it will only be possible to pay six months' salary to each teacher of an Indian day school between September 1, 1940, and March 31, 1941. As a result it was suggested in our previous circular that the schools should be closed for the month of September. If, however, you would prefer the Whitefish Bay School to remain open in September and close for any other month between the dates mentioned above you might let me know.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

As you have been previously notified Mr Armand LaFleche, teacher at the Whitefish Bay Day School, has passed his examinations and is now a B.A. and M.A. and with these qualifications is fitted to take a larger and better position teaching.

I am informed he is trying to get a better position in Manitoba and has applied for positions in High Schools, and it is quite possible he may get some such position, in which case he would naturally leave the Whitefish School.

I have requested him to give us as much notice as possible should he intend leaving our School, so that another teacher could be procured, without holding up the education of the children, this I feel sure he will do if at all possible.

If the Department could see their way clear to recommend an increase of pay for him he might possibly stay with us, but I would not like to jeopardise his future by suggesting he stay.

We are, of course, not making it public that he may leave us, nor the Indians who like him, and do not wish him to leave.

This for your information.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 29, 1941.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to Mr. Armand LaFleche, teacher of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School. Even though an increase were given Mr. LaFleche, it would be a small amount, and I agree with you that in his own best interests he should endeavour to secure more remunerative employment. The present seems an opportune time for him to act in this way. In making this statement I do not wish to imply that we are not satisfied with his services, because all reports indicate that he has done splendid work. However, as you know, there is a limit to salaries of teachers of Indian day schools beyond which we cannot go.

We will keep your recommendation in mind, and in the event of Mr. LaFleche deciding to stay in our employment for another year, arrangements will be made to grant him a small increase before October first.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
